Award.AwardTitle: Impacts of Enhanced Cloud Condensation Nuclei (CCN) on the Organization of Convection for Monsoon Depressions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to understand the effect of aerosol pollution on monsoon depressions. Monsoon depressions are synoptic-scale systems (2,000km to 3,000km) with baroclinic (or tilted) vertical structure which propagate westward, forming in the Bay of Bengal and producing as much as 150 to 200 mm of rainfall during their passage over any location. They occur during the monsoon season, when the vertical shear of the zonal wind is strong enough to inhibit the formation of hurricane-strength tropical cyclones, and they are distinct from weaker but similar systems called "monsoon lows", which have a barotropic (or upright) vertical structure. The Principal Investigator argues that the heavy aerosol pollution found over the Indian sector causes a reduction in the frequency of occurrence of monsoon depressions. This claim is based on several lines of evidence: first, there has been a dramatic reduction in the occurrence of monsoon depressions, from an annual average of 7 to 8 historically to 1, 0, and 2 in the years 2009, 2010, and 2011. Second, aerosol pollution has increased dramatically over the Indian sector in recent years. Third, global forecast models, which presumably do not account for the change in aerosol pollution, have overpredicted monsoon depressions in the recent years with few depressions. Fourth, preliminary experiments with the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model show that the strength of monsoon depressions, and the intensity and organization of precipitation within them, can be dramatically reduced by increasing the aerosol burden from relatively pristine (5x10^8 particles per cubic meter) to heavily polluted (5x10^10 per cubic meter) values. The research is based on the hypothesis that aerosols suppress monsoon depressions because they slow the formation of rainfall, as more aerosols lead to more cloud condensation nuclei (CCN), which produce a greater number of smaller cloud droplets, which take longer to coalesce into raindrops. Monsoon depressions form through a mutual interaction between the baroclinic/barotropic instability of the large-scale flow and the latent heat of condensation accompanying precipitation within the depression. This mutual interaction can be suppressed by the excess aerosols, which increase time required for the development of precipitation by roughly a factor of two, and thus produce a mismatch between the timescales of the hydrodynamic instability and the organization of precipitation and accompanying latent heat release. Work performed under this award tests the hypothesized suppression of monsoon depressions by aerosol pollution using more sophisticated and realistic simulations, and also performs analysis of aerosol forcing, based on satellite data, during periods when monsoon depressions form and when they are absent.

The suppression of monsoon depressions addressed in this research is of both scientific and societal interest, given the large population that is affected by them. If successful, the results of this work could be directly applied to operational forecasting systems used to predict these weather systems. In addition, the project provides support and training for a postdoc and a graduate student, thereby providing for the next generation of scientists in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Impacts of Enhanced Cloud Condensation Nuclei (CCN) on the Organization of Convection for Monsoon Depressions

Award Number 1241292

The March of the onset of the monsoon from near the equator to the foothills of the Himalayas occurs during the month of June every year and takes roughly 4 weeks for this traverse. Some years this motion is fast and in other years it is slow. This is a very difficult monsoon forecast problem. In the course of our modeling (using the WRF-CHEM model) we compared the results of two sets of experiments, one with the heavy aerosols (CHEM) and the other with no aerosols (WRF). These are week long averages from a 7-day integration. The 20 m/s isotach for the experiment with the heavy aerosols shows a more southerly shift compared to the experiment with no aerosols. Furthermore, the intensity of the Somali jet, > 60 m/s, for the heavy aerosol experiment is about 5 m/s stronger compared to the no aerosol experiment. In this heavy aerosol experiment stronger winds reach well south of Sri Lanka with winds in excess of 20 m/s. This can be interpreted as a stronger and more southerly Somali Jet as it extends across the Arabian sea. This has implications on the model forecasts of monsoon onset rains. The experiment with heavy aerosols delays the onset of the monsoon over the southwest coast of India (the Kerala onset). The precipitation fields for the difference in rainfall for the two experiments, CHEM and WRF, were also examined. The onset of monsoon rains in Kerala during June 2009 were delayed. The difference shows that the rains over southern India were deficient in the heavy aerosol experiment as compared to the experiment with no aerosols. This deficiency of rain in the heavy aerosol experiment implies a slower advance of the monsoon over peninsular India when the aerosols were high. In this same illustration, the strong 30 m/s winds over the central Arabian sea led to enhanced evaporation over the open ocean causing more rains in the experiment with the heavy aerosols (CHEM) as compared to the experiment that had no aerosols (WRF). This difference of the rains over land and ocean was an interesting aspect of the CHEM experiment. The southward shift of the Somali jet is attributed to the formation of an anticyclonic feature over the northern Arabian sea where the aerosols accumulate and cause some cooling of lower tropospheric temperatures. The easterly wind anomalies to the south of this anticyclone play a role in pushing the westerlies of the Somali Jet southwards.

 

Numerous studies on the effects of aerosols on the behavior of the Asian monsoon have appeared in the literature in recent years. These studies have addressed observational, modeling and aerosol effects of the first and second kind, i.e. from chemistry/microphysics and radiative transfer. The early observational work of Twomey and Albrecht were very useful for the basic understanding of the impacts of aerosols on the generation of CCNs. We had noted that the organization of convection in newly forming monsoon depressions starts with shear flow dynamics involving horizontal and vertical shear. Using the WRF-CHEM model our study addressed modeling results for “with” and “without” aerosols. Monsoon depressions formed in the experiments without the aerosols, and the organization of convection was preserved and amplified, whereas in the experiments with heavy aerosols a disruption of the organization was noted. In these latter experiments a large population of CCN's developed over a wide area resulting in a slow growth of new clouds over the lower half of the upper troposphere. This large population of clouds consumed the available large-scale supply of moisture, thus leaving a shortage of moisture availability for organized convection around monsoon depressions; those weakened and died. The observations in recent years show a decline in the population of monsoon depressions, reaching a value of zero depressions during the summer monsoon of 2010, whereas the normal count has been around 7 to 8 depressions in a season. These same types of effects of disruption of the organization of convection have also been modeled for hurricanes that encountered heavy aerosol incursions of the Saharan Air Layer.
